qas.question: How many times has the exemption process been used, as of 2009?
What were the results of those exemption petitions?

answers.text: one was granted, one was partially granted, one was denied and three were withdrawn

qas.question: Why is this exemption provision often considered a nonfactor?

answers.text: few consultations result in jeopardy opinions

qas.question: How can jeopardy opinions be dissuaded?

answers.text: in the identification of reasonable and prudent alternatives to avoid jeopardy.

qas.question: How many exemptions were granted in 2009?
What is a key factor for the ESA?
What did Donald Baur write in 2009?
How many exemptions were withdrawn in 2009?
How many exemptions has Donald Baur ruled on?

context: There have been <a0_0><b8_0>six<b8_0/><a0_0/> instances as of 2009 in which the exemption process was initiated. Of these six, <a1_0><b4_0>one<b4_0/> was granted, one was partially granted, one was denied and <b7_0>three<b7_0/> were withdrawn<a1_0/>. Donald Baur, in <b6_0>The Endangered Species Act<b6_0/>: law, policy, and perspectives, concluded," ... <b5_0>the exemption provision<b5_0/> is basically a nonfactor in the administration of the ESA. A major reason, of course, is that so <a2_0>few consultations result in jeopardy opinions<a2_0/>, and those that do almost always result <a3_0>in the identification of reasonable and prudent alternatives to avoid jeopardy.<a3_0/>"
